awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2024 Climate Engineering GRC and GRS
awd_abstract_narration:
The 2024 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on Climate Engineering (CE) will be held February 18-23, 2024 in Lucca, Italy. The conference will feature both senior and junior scientists who recently have been active in the field and are leading new research directions in climate engineering research. Scientists and engineers spanning researchers who did some of the first work in this area to students currently basing their graduate research in climate engineering are anticipated to attend. The Gordon Research Seminar (GRS), designed for young scientists, will precede the GRC at the same location on February 17 and 18. This grant is for partial support of US-based invited speakers, discussion leaders and others, in particular early-career scientists, to attend the GRS and GRC. Areas to be discussed include: the engineering and technical feasibility of climate engineering approaches; how implementation of CE would affect climate impacts; detectability and interpretation of impacts, including societal and ecological considerations; and approaches for designing injection strategies and CE scenarios to study the outcomes of different CE applications under different climate scenarios. Research to be discussed also includes improving confidence in Earth system models through evaluation with observations and model intercomparisons. The study of Climate Engineering is by nature interdisciplinary, relying on information exchange and in-depth discussions between different groups, as provided by the GRC and GRS.

Climate change is continuing to cause large-scale impacts and extreme events all over the world. Climate Engineering via solar radiation modification (SRM) may be the only option to sustain global temperatures in the near term. However, understanding of the feasibility and impacts of different SRM approaches is still very limited, which is limiting ability to make well-informed decisions about their possible use. Furthermore, the needed technologies have not been developed. There is therefore an urgent need to accelerate climate engineering research, ideally bringing fragmented research areas together towards more focused work. The GRC and GRS are excellent venues to discuss cutting-edge CE research and ideas and to integrate an interdisciplinary group of scientists to move the research forward. This 2024 GRC/GRS for climate engineering is located in Italy, with the purpose of allowing researchers from all over the world, and in particular from developing countries, to more easily attend. The GRS will play an important role in introducing and integrating early career scientists and students into critical topic areas of CE research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Climate engineering of Solar Radiation Modification (SRM) methods, also called solar geoengineering, is an emerging research topic. Recent assessments by the U.K. Royal Society in 2009, assessment reports by the U.S. National Academy of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine in 2015 and 2021 (NASEM 2015 & 2021), and the United Nations Environment Program in 2023 have endorsed scientific research on the feasibility, efficacy, and impacts of SRM. The combined Gordon Research Conference (GRC) and Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) in 2024, with their emphasis on featuring speakers from developing nations doing SRM research, supported these goals more than most scientific conferences. 

As one of the world’s best and most established meeting formats in the physical sciences, the GRC and GRS provide an extraordinary opportunity to accelerate the quality and frequency of scientific discourse on this topic. Following the 2017 and 2022 meetings, the GRC for Climate Engineering in 2024, as continuously supported by NSF, has been a great continuation of the meeting in previous years and has still been the premier scientific meeting in this emerging field. In addition, the GRS provided a forum that was specifically aimed at early-career researchers to build confidence and build bridges that better enable early-career researchers from all over the world to participate more fully in the GRC.  

This year’s GRC conference program included a diverse range of speakers and discussion leaders from institutions and organizations worldwide, concentrating on the latest developments in the field. The conference was five days long and held in a remote location to increase the sense of camaraderie and create scientific communities with lasting collaborations and friendships. The keynote talks on the first day featured SRM approaches and simulations by leading experts (with one from India). These talks provided a foundation and broader understanding of the content for the interdisciplinary participants. The second day covered lectures that discussed the latest research and understanding of the basic science of SRM, with a focus on the main proposed climate engineering methods. The next day of the program focused on observational analogs of SRM as well as global climate responses and attribution. Addressing the usefulness of observational analogs is essential for SRM research since it enables to assess and evaluate modeling results. The talks on global climate responses covered important considerations on actionable science and detecting climate impacts. This session was followed by a session on climate responses and impacts of SRM in Developing Nations. Talks reaching from process level understanding to the impact of SRM in various areas allowed the important exchange of research that produced model simulations and those that used them for impact analysis in particular in nations that are most impacted by climate change. The same day, the interdisciplinary session on impacts on the carbon cycle, agriculture, and ocean biodiversity further stressed the need for broadening the area of climate engineering research. Discussions supported that Climate Engineering requires a broad range of scientific disciplines from climate science to economics to engineering, and many sub-disciplines within climate science. The meeting concluded with discussions of the design principles and engineering to determine options that best balance different outcomes, tipping points, and a final keynote on exploring the climate engineering scenario space. Unlike climate change, where research is more linear, climate engineering research must be more integrated, whereby strategy and scenario design need to be informed by what engineering solutions are achievable, physical constraints of the climate system, and how climate impacts and risks can be reduced.  

The GRC and GRS program supports the professional growth of all members of our communities, including ethnicity, race and/or gender identity, by providing an open forum for discussion and mentoring. In this context, the GRC included the so-called GRC Power Hour, which was visited this time by about 30-40 participants. The GRC Power Hour is a venue established by the GRC to address diversity and inclusion in the scientific workplace by providing a safe environment for informal and meaningful conversations amongst colleagues of all career stages. It was a great opportunity to discuss issues, needs and solutions to improve diversity and inclusion and learn from different approaches in developing and developed countries.

A mix of senior scientists and early career presenters allowed well rounded representation of the research done in this still young field. In addition to premier talks, the conference had designated time for poster sessions from individuals of all career stages, and afternoon free time and communal meals allowed for informal networking opportunities with leaders in the field. The Full Program can be viewed on our website here: https://www.grc.org/climate-engineering-conference/2024/
